body:
@gilbertoca I think the most (or some) people will agree with that solution and find it nice, but someone has to hook that topic up and change the current wizard to the new one. And to say that, it was my idea but I will not find time to do that, unfortunately.

So we have some options/opinions:
1. Leave it as it is now and close this PR
2. Use a fast and maybe quick win solution i.e. that what Geertjan said (Not perfect but for the first run it is a nice to have)
3. You or someone else will take this to his own project and change it to the better solution.

@gilbertoca that also assumes that each build system has the same project type requirements, and at the moment at least they don't overlap.  It may be a bit of work to try and make them overlap, and might be less understandable if they did (eg. what's the generic variant of `POM Project`?)

@gilbertoca I'm not sure I understand your question.  I don't think the idea is complex technically, I think the idea is complex _for the user_.  The three build systems have different project types.  At least in the proposal outlined by Geertjan all the options are still easily discoverable.  Until there's a good _user facing_ way to categorize those different types of project across build systems, I think we need build system as the first choice.

@neilcsmith-net I don't think, that we need it as a first choice, because what happens when there is more popular stuff is coming? Like for JS? The first view of the new projects shouldn't that overloaded with options. Go choose your language and later you can choose the build system. But yes, this is your opinion and this is my opinion, maybe we should make a vote later for this.

I think we should only do a vote on a unified wizard once we have a commitment from someone to actually implement that. And it will not be trivial to implement. :-) (Plus, as @neilcsmith-net points out, it may end up being a lot less intuitive than the current situation for end users. Don't forget that all changes have unintended side effects, so it's better to make changes as small as possible.)

Today, I will create a PR for the proposal I suggested above and that seems to have everyone's approval -- "Java with Maven", "Java with Gradle", and "Java with Ant", in that order, with all the project templates related to Java organized into those three categories.
Here is the newly created issue with full description: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-2040

Here is the PR: https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/1115
Here is the blog with pic: https://blogs.apache.org/netbeans/entry/restructuring-of-project-templates-in
I do not know if it matters anything, but +1 for this PR. An thanks for the bolgpost as well!
Looks good to me too.

Since this represents the concluding points of various discussions, and since no one is objecting, I am merging this. If strong objections emerge, we can revert; if tweaks are needed on the basis of this starting point, we can always tweak and modify as needed. But in the spirit of ‘get it done’, I am now going to merge this.
My PR is merged. As a consequence, since Maven is now first, as requested via this PR, I am closing this PR.
I needed this one to move forward.
Late to the party but +1 to this PR as well. Thanks.

@geertjanw please have a look at this. The `empty.jar` was reintroduced by your commit in: 9b3eed220c3988b68634794e234c58a5126cda02 .

The easiest fix would have been to just remove empty.war again and add it to .gitignore, but I think building the war at runtime ensures, that there is no file, that can be accidentally committed.

The commit on master:
```
commit a0eedc59ce2cc347d7e07b0a20f2fdd3c0b6c93d (HEAD -> master, origin/master)
Author: Laszlo Kishalmi <laszlo.kishalmi@gmail.com>
Date:   Sat Feb 2 13:27:44 2019 -0800

    [NETBEANS-2001] Fix Typos in Gradle dialog Boxes.

```
misses a small thing which I have solved.
Thank you for spotting that!

`BASE_DIR=`pwd`
NB_ALL=$BASE_DIR
export BASE_DIR NB_ALL

DIST=$BASE_DIR/dist
export DIST

if [ -d $DIST ] ; then
    rm -rf $DIST
fi

mkdir -p $DIST/zip/moduleclusters
mkdir -p $DIST/logs

cp /scratch/downloads/NetBeans-dev-incubator-netbeans-linux-996-on-20190203-release.zip $DIST/zip/moduleclusters

NB_BUILD_NUMBER=2019
BASENAME_PREFIX=Apache-NetBeans-11.0-bin
BUILD_DESC=$BASENAME_PREFIX
BUILDNUMBER=2019
DATESTAMP=$BUILDNUMBER

export BUILDNUMBER BASENAME_PREFIX NB_BUILD_NUMBER DATESTAMP BUILD_DESC

LOCALES=ja,zh_CN,pt_BR,ru
export LOCALES
JDK11_BUILDS_PATH=artifactory/re-release-local/jdk/11.0.1/13/bundles/
export JDK7_BUILDS_PATH JDK8_BUILDS_PATH JDK11_BUILDS_PATH

MAC_SIGN_CLIENT=
MAC_SIGN_USER=
MAC_SIGN_GUID=
CODESIGNBUREAU_CREDFILE=

export MAC_SIGN_CLIENT
export MAC_SIGN_USER
export MAC_SIGN_GUID
export CODESIGNBUREAU_CREDFILE


NATIVE_MAC_MACHINE=reemataneja@<hostip>
MAC_PATH=/Users/reemataneja/installer/
export NATIVE_MAC_MACHINE
export MAC_PATH

MAC_LOG_NEW=$DIST/logs/native_mac-$BUILDNUMBER.log
export MAC_LOG_NEW
BUILD_NB=1
BUILD_NETBEANS=0
BUILD_NBJDK6=0
BUILD_NBJDK7=0
BUILD_NBJDK8=0
BUILD_NBJDK11=0

export BUILD_NETBEANS BUILD_NB
export BUILD_NBJDK6 BUILD_NBJDK7 BUILD_NBJDK8 BUILD_NBJDK11
BUNDLE_JDK_PLATFORM=
export BUNDLE_JDK_PLATFORM

OUTPUT_DIR=${NB_ALL}/dist/installers
export OUTPUT_DIR

DONT_SIGN_INSTALLER=y
export DONT_SIGN_INSTALLER


bash -x $NB_ALL/nbbuild/newbuild/build-nbi.sh
Above script can be run to create Apache NetBeans installers for Windows, Linux and Mac OSX

Btw. Alas one of my fixes in [graal](http://github.com/oracle/graal) caused a regression elsewhere and thus they were backed out from current master. I'll work on polishing them and getting them in for RC13.

Maybe it's good to mention that preferring class files to source files has some limitations.
The find usages (refactoring) will not work on source level annotations, static fields initialized by compilation time constant, etc.
I am not saying that's a big problem but should be known.

Another limitation comes from annotation processing. There will be no sources generated by AP only binaries.

I am not sure how this will behave when the project is using annotation processors generating sources. Did you try that?
Thanks

> Maybe it's good to mention that preferring class files to source files has some limitations.

Right. Another reason for the support to be opt-in only.

> The find usages (refactoring) will not work on source level annotations, static fields initialized by compilation time constant, etc.

Right.

> Another limitation comes from annotation processing. There will be no sources generated by AP only binaries.

In the `mx` based projects, I can put the `src_gen` folder on some classpath. E.g. the sources will be there, it is just a question whether IDE finds them... I will need to test this change on the real `mx` projects before merging it to make sure it really works.

@lkishalmi does this PR supersede #1114 with regard to Spring Boot gradle projects? Or can they co-exist?

In NBSpringBoot plugin I actually used the action mapping feature for maven projects in order to map the run and debug actions to different maven goals (i.e. use `spring-boot:run` instead of `exec:exec` for the run action) but only for projects generated with the plugin itself.

I'm sorry for a late reply. After looking into the related classes/methods (TokenSequence.embedded() and createEmbedding(); EmbeddingOperation class etc.) currently there is no mechanism of preferring a language embedding for a display. The SyntaxHighlighting.HSImpl.moveTheSequence() currently picks the TokenSequence.embedded() which gets the first embedded token list (they are singly linked list by EmbeddedTokenList.nextEmbeddedTokenList). To modify this there would have to be some sort of registry added where SyntaxHighlighting would look and if there would be an explicit embedded Language registered for a given LanguagePath then the SyntaxHighlighting would attempt TokenSequence.embedded(registered-language) first before defaulting to TokenSequence.embedded().

> @lkishalmi does this PR supersede #1114 with regard to Spring Boot gradle projects? Or can they co-exist?
> 
> In NBSpringBoot plugin I actually used the action mapping feature for maven projects in order to map the run and debug actions to different maven goals (i.e. use `spring-boot:run` instead of `exec:exec` for the run action) but only for projects generated with the plugin itself.

The #1114 is for Gradle SpringBoot projects, where the main task is named as "bootRun" and yes these two PR-s are independent and can coexist in the main code.

Regarding APs, the tricky aspect might be when the APs need to read the sources from previous compilation iterations in incremental compilation. It may even be necessary to copy the sources as well.

I appreciate that the API was adjusted to a more common structure.

Overall, I don't have problem with this patch.

> Is this a real issue?

Well I think so yes considering that they don't pass successfully (they are using external resources that don't even exist anymore)! And IMHO integration tests shouldn't be executed in the same lifecycle as unit tests...
The "nb-" prefix has been removed from the properties.

Well, I've seen this one happening while accidentally caught it on the debugger.
As File.exists() returns false on a broken symlink, any change triggers a refresh in a watched folder that has a broken symlink triggers this code resulting a folder children refresh which again triggers this code over and over.

Can I merge this PR with the failing tests I've created? I'm sorry but I was not able to make the required test. Also we need to think about how we are eventually handle broken symlinks, as my tests at least could point out there is an inconsistency.
Also this really be part of 11.0 as Gradle Projects are definitely triggers this issue.
I guess part of this one (or the whole) shall be reverted and a new nb-javac like solution shall be integrated,

Please see also:
https://github.com/arusinha/incubator-netbeans/pull/2
Seems to be trivial enough. Travis approves. Let's merge it.
Any progress on this?
Maybe this is just a packaging problem. But I'm a bit disappointed, that @dukescript ignores this.
Only to let you know, that is not only gradle related. All started w/o using/knowing gradle. FYI.

Gradle has a bug in it that triggers it: https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/8119
But it is a general problem, it can happen if there (watched directory from NB filesystem) is a broken link from any reason...

> I am sorry, but there should be tests for the change. In some cases, it is difficult to say if the code works in some particular place without seeing a (presumably passing) testcase.

Had added test-cases in recent commit.

Ok - Apache legal gave its verdict: As long as we use the icon in the way we plan (as an icon representing the programm), it is fair use. We also need a valid license, that satisfies the requirements of the apache foundation regarding the copy right. Using the CC-0 licensed base will keep the copy right easy and the trademark part is covered by fair use. @Chris2011 is suggest, you follow the advise from https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/1034#issuecomment-453753472
@jlahoda Thanks for the tip using FileUtil.urlForArchiveOrDir! It makes the whole method much better and simpler!

FWIW, review for a patch that actually removes the old javadoc API from JDK:
https://mail.openjdk.java.net/pipermail/javadoc-dev/2019-February/000848.html
Approved

hey @matthiasblaesing great news. Thx. Will do so. But i want to add the icon to the package-lock.json and npm-debug.log. Do I need to ask again for permission for those files? I mean those files are also part of that and shouldn't be a problem, right?

Please feel free to reopen if you have changes to be discussed.
Excellent, I think we should merge this.
I suggest this be moved into the 'nbbuild' folder, rather than being a top level 'installer' folder, once that's done, I'm in favor of approving this.
Yes, good to go.
Should we include this for 11.0 or close it?
Merging, not squashing.
Is this still needed now that we have multi-jar support added already since this issue was created?
It might be needed, I've compared with #965 and these stuff are different. It would be good if the author could answer/retry the testcase. I simply have no time for that now.
I would be ok with using the icon for the two files. There is a direct relationship from `package.json`, `package-lock.json` and `npm-debug.log` to npm. Using the icon seems logical.
Well, this is really needed for the Out of the Box Gradle Experience. Merging now. If someone has issues with this he can still report that later.
Well, let's see what our CI tells about this one.
OK - no problem. I am addressing all the issues raised by Jaroslav and will re-open this or make a new PR for the new approach.

Actually, I don't think I can re-open a PR that @lkishalmi has closed.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21333654/how-to-re-open-an-issue-in-github
When the time comes I will ask you...

For what it's worth (I guess not much if it's fair use anyway), I think it's completely reasonable to use the same logo for package.json as package-lock.json and npm-debug.log files.

Glad to hear this reached a reasonable resolution :)
Great thx to @isaacs for your help and patience and thx to @matthiasblaesing for the help and the legal part. Will do it in the next couple of days :)
I've checked with today's Jenkins build (1013) on Java 11 and the issue I reported has been fix by other module related changes.  Thanks for looking at it, I'll close the pull request.
Sorry, I haven't had time to look into the tests yet. I'll try to get them done during the next couple of weeks now that our product release is over and done with.
Thanks.
Eclipse GlassFish 5.1 is available, from the Eclipse Foundation. Maybe support could be added for downloading that too?

Provided nothing major has changed, downloading & installing should be a simple matter of adding new entries for GF5.1 to necessary enums/properties files.

The slightly bigger piece of work would be updating NB UI to dynamically change the target of the licence link, so that if GF5.1 were selected, it would point to the new EF licence
Can you explain, i.e., which enum/properties files need to be changed, or do it? Would be great to be able to support 5.1, since that's the latest release.

Sure thing! I'll try and find some time tonight/tomorrow to create a feature request in Jira for GF5.1, with the steps I think need to be followed - somebody can have a crack at it to get in it for 11.0 (I'm going to be away for a couple of weeks..)
Would be great, thanks!
Here's the related download page: https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/ee4j.glassfish/downloads

Thanks for doing this work @peedeeboy.  It would be great if GlassFish 5.1 could be added, as it marks a major milestone for the platform.  I think that GlassFish 3.1.2.2 should be removed as a choice.   It is probably a bad practice for developers to be using such an old server.  Thoughts?

+1 

I'll leave it to you Josh and other Java/Jakarta EE aficionados to recommend minimum/recommended release numbers for GlassFish -- and ideally @peedeeboy's instructions should be sufficient for this to be updated/added/changed as needed without too much work.

Seems OK to me.
The reasoning in the issue is sound and the change looks good. Will merge.

Thank you for tackling this. A bit more background information would be good though. If I read this correctly, the `nb-extra-files` are explicitly excluded from the zip file, so excluding them from the license file seems sane. This raises the question, why they are placed in the build directory in the first place. If they are not there, we don't need a hack to ignore them.

The `extra` cluster has traditionally been a place where additional modules (for example from original [contrib](http://hg.netbeans.org/main/contrib) repository) end up.

The purpose of the `extra` cluster is to support local development without influencing packaging of the distributions. One can build any module, and that module is available when one does `ant tryme`. However no such additional module influences content of ZIP produced by `ant build`.

> A bit more background information would be good though

The `extra` cluster is also a place where NBM files downloaded into installation location end up (unless they specify cluster by themselves). I suggested @eppleton to use the `extra` cluster _trashbin_ for #917. Unless I am mistaken the overall idea is [described in this comment](https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/917#issuecomment-439595927).
Build failures seem to be because of rat related issues, looking into these.

Thank you for the pointer and explanation Jaroslav, that helped me to understand. Maybe this could be considered as an enhancement to the change:

```diff
--- a/nbbuild/build.xml
+++ b/nbbuild/build.xml
@@ -79,6 +79,12 @@
             <include name="platform/javahelp/external/binaries-list"/>
         </manifest>
     </downloadbinaries>
+    <!--
+    nb-extra-files denotes directories/files, that are not packed for
+    distribution. The clusters are only used for local development/testing.
+    The files must not be included in distribution zip and also need to be
+    excluded from license analysis
+    -->
     <property name="nb-extra-files" value="test/**,extra/**"/>
 
     <echo message="Bootstrapping NetBeans-specific Ant extensions..."/>
```

Though either way, for a license perspective this looks good to me (I did a build and checked the LICENSE file of the result zip).

However, I don't see that it works. I used the above mentioned zip, extracted it and run it with a clean user+cache dir. I would now expect the "Embedded Browser UI - JavaFX WebView" plugin to be activeable (requirering me to install javafx), but this is not the case. I don't see an option to install JavaFX as a plugin. What am I missing?

I did testing on IGV and things seem to work relatively well. Let's integrated. @lkishalmi, please consider backporting this into `release110` branch. That would make it easier for some future version of IGV to use the new API.

I did some testing with [NETBEANS-2131](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-2131) and [NETBEANS-2132](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-2132) the scenarios described in there work (they were broken in NetBeans 10 on JDK11) to some extent.

I haven't considered the "Embedded Browser UI" usecase so far. It may need few more fixes to get it working, but it should be possible as far as I can tell.
Closing this, as the requesting account was removed and the PR is stalled.
Does this need cherry picking added for the Apache NetBeans 11 branch?

Any reason not to merge this at this stage? Everything will be within a new folder 'installer' in the 'nbbuild' folder. Instructions for using it are above. We'll be able to produce installers for Apache NetBeans 11 and deliver them as convenience binaries together with the ZIP that provides the convenience binary. No JRE or JDK is bundled with this installer, they are expected to be available on the user's machine and the installer fails with a message if they're not available.
Should we include this for 11.0 or close it?

> Avoiding the compilation of Javac during NetBeans build is in my opinion desirable. CCing @jlahoda... The `nb-javac-*-*.jar` files can only be used during compilation, but as far as I know it is the case.

Would be good to see the compilation go away, but:
-just using nb-javac will simply mean the baseline JDK on which we can run without nb-javac is JDK 12. If that's the move we want to make, I am fairly sure some changes elsewhere will be needed as well. (NoJavacHelper and ergonomics come to mind,)
-using nb-javac(-impl) will mean the modules (besides java.source.nbjavac) might accidentally use some nb-javac specific API, which would hamper the ability to run without nb-javac.

These are the main reasons why the build compiles against a vanilla/unmodified javac. The reason why the build compiles it from source is that then the conditions of the javac license are met vacuously, I believe.

So, I've got a Part B to this PR, that does the following:

- Adds the licence location for each version of GlassFish to the ServerDetails enum
- Removes the JOptionPane pop-up and instead adds a JComboBox above the Download button
- Clicking to view license details opens the correct webpage for the currently selected GF version
- Changing GlassFish version deselects the checkbox, so the user has to confirm again that they have read the license.

What is the easiest way to merge these together?
I'm getting a warning on build about a Netbeans API change.  Is this due to ServerDetails being in a Public package?  How to resolve this?

Git diff attached
[diff.txt](https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/files/2906759/diff.txt)

Excellent! I don't think yours and mine need to be merged together, they're quite separate, I think, i.e., create a new issue and a new PR, I don't think there will be conflicts between yours and mine? Don't know about the ServerDetails item.

Temporarily closing this while I'm making changes to make installer build job pass.

OK, merging.

@jtulach Added a test case for substituting the fragment bundle with its host bundle in NetigsoLoader. It currently uses a little bit of reflection since NetigsoModule wraps NetigsoLoader inside some sort of private wrapper class loader, and I can't get access to it otherwise.
